channel.title: NPR All Things Considered
channel.description: All Things Considered hosts Ailsa Chang, Mary Louise Kelly, Ari Shapiro, Juana Summers and Scott Detrow present the program's trademark mix of news, interviews, commentaries, reviews, and offbeat features 7 days a week.

item.title: A growing number of 20-somethings are getting what's known as 'baby Botox'
item.description: A growing number of 20-somethings are trying to stop wrinkles from forming on their face with a preventative treatment known as "baby Botox," which freezes facial muscles to limit movement.

item.title: Too much to pack, not enough hugs: A Kenyan man's last 48 hours in America
item.description: Samuel Kangethe has lived in the U.S. for nearly two decades, but an unresolved immigration case has made him deportable. He's decided to return to Kenya, leaving his wife and three children behind.

item.title: A remembrance of Dale Webster, who surfed for 40 years
item.description: Friends remember Dale Webster, who surfed every day for decades, and who died this month at the age of 76.

item.title: Climate change brings tropical fruits to high-altitude Mexico City
item.description: Mexico City is not known for its tropical fruits. But climate change is causing some garden surprises.

item.title: The International Association of Chiefs of Police calls for more transparency from ICE
item.description: The International Association of Chiefs of Police has issued two resolutions focused on ICE agents' use of face masks and heated comments around policing coming from influential leaders. Ari Shapiro speaks with Terrence Cunningham, a retired police chief and head of the IACP.

item.title: This year's U.S. Open is a redemption of sorts for American Taylor Townsend
item.description: American tennis player Taylor Townsend is gearing up for the U.S. Open. She'll take to the court as the top-ranked doubles player. Her story is one of resilience and overcoming preconceived notions.

item.title: In France, debate heats up over air conditioning
item.description: The politics of air conditioning in France, as the country basks in yet another heatwave.

item.title: This community is trying something new to keep rat numbers down: birth control
item.description: No one wants rats scurrying about their neighborhood. But they're a cunning and evasive foe. Now, a community near Boston is trying their luck with a different approach: rat birth control.

item.title: In navigating hearing loss, poet Raymond Antrobus explains his views on 'deaf gain'
item.description: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks to poet Raymond Antrobus about his new memoir, The Quiet Ear, and how he has navigated between the worlds of hearing and hearing loss.

item.title: A church in Sweden is being relocated down the road in one piece
item.description: A historic 113-year-old church is being moved a few miles down the road -- in one piece.
